quote: Cat 3 report. Around 50 men in the field with a handful of P/1/2 women, who they combined with us. Chris and I staged toward the back, not worrying too much about position given the neutral start and expected the usual 'lap 1 warm up' we've been accustomed to in the 3s. OOPS.

One thing about Purgatory is there are lots of twists and turns in narrow wooded roads so it's perfect for a break really. I also found out (once I did move up) that there were very few guys willing to work at the front.
I love Purgatory because it's held on the roads I train on every day, yet I can't master this one. Weird race, overall. It sums up the Cat 3 New England racing scene this year.
The pace in the Pro 1/2 field was furious from the start. With a handful of teams well represented, the peloton struggled to find the right composition of riders to let up the road.

With 7 laps of the 11 mile course scheduled for the P1/2 field and the mercury tickling 88 degrees, it became a war of attrition. First to fall was Travis, his day complete after 30 miles of racing. Next to pop was Dan, who spent the first 3 laps in nearly every break that went up the road...
Much like the P1/2 event, the early laps had some inspired racing but with no major teams represented 2 riders were allowed to get up the road and build a 1 minute advantage on the third lap.
